question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Be careful to ensure that the generated code is executable for demonstration. I am a biology teacher and need help designing an HTML webpage for a virtual experiment demonstration of the spread plate technique for a biology class. The webpage should include experimental materials and equipment: test tubes with yeast culture broth, cotton plugs, solid culture medium, inoculation loops, alcohol lamp (flammable), clean bench, and inoculation loops. The material and tool icons should be aesthetically pleasing and resemble actual images, with colors matching the real objects. Icons should be positioned on both sides of the page, movable, and highly interactive.

checklist.title: Is the spread plate technique procedure accurately implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements all key steps of the spread plate technique (sterilizing the loop, cooling, sampling, inoculation, spreading, incubation). Score 0 if core procedure steps are missing, 5 if basic steps are implemented but lack scientific accuracy, and 10 if all microbiology protocols are followed with proper sequence and safety considerations.

checklist.title: Are all required experimental materials and equipment fully implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether all materials (test tubes with yeast culture broth, cotton plugs, solid culture medium, inoculation loops, alcohol lamp, clean bench) are implemented with proper visual representation. Deduct 2 points for each missing item. All items must be interactive and movable. Full implementation with accurate visual representation scores 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the drag-and-drop interaction system properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate the quality of the drag-and-drop system for moving experimental tools. Check for smooth animation (60fps), precise positioning, proper z-index management, and intuitive interaction. Deduct 3 points if there's noticeable lag, 3 points if tool positioning is imprecise, and 4 points if tools can't be reliably manipulated. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Are experimental safety procedures and scientific accuracy maintained?
checklist.description: Assess if the simulation enforces proper microbiology safety protocols (flame sterilization, aseptic technique, contamination prevention) and follows scientific accuracy. Deduct 5 points if critical safety procedures are missing or incorrect. Deduct 5 points if the simulation allows scientifically impossible actions. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as rapid multiple clicks, dropping objects in invalid areas, browser resizing) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the learning experience (e.g., 1. Microscopic view of yeast cells 2. Time-lapse of colony growth 3. Quiz integration to test student knowledge). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple drag-and-drop systems) 2. Function modules unrelated to the spread plate technique (e.g., unrelated biological processes) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., excessive animations that distract from learning). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating experiment logic/view/interaction layers), code organization, and maintainability. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if there's no clear separation of concerns. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional educational design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether material and tool icons are aesthetically pleasing and resemble actual lab equipment with accurate colors. Check for: 1) Visual clarity and high-quality graphics 2) Proper layout with tools easily accessible on both sides of the page 3) Clear visual instructions and labels. Deduct 3 points for each low-quality or unrealistic icon, 5 points for poor layout of materials, and 5 points for confusing visual hierarchy. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and educational?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects support learning objectives: 1) Clear visual feedback when tools are used correctly/incorrectly 2) Appropriate animation speed that matches real laboratory timing 3) Instructional cues that guide proper technique. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for animations that are too fast to observe properly, and 5 points for missing educational guidance during critical steps. The full score is 10 points.
